body: I'll close the issue as the PR is now merged into master branch.

@xadupre does the fix solves also the problem if the inputs of the `OneHotEncoder` are strings?

I'm facing a similar situation with one `OneHotEncoder` in front of a `XGBRegressor`: the output is of course not 0s (because of the regressor), but it is always the same value given.

@xadupre some clarification:
- I'm comparing the predictions via onnxruntime and sklearn/xgboost itself and the there are huge differences when using the `OneHotEncoder`
- I tried with the latest master of `sklearn-onnx` and the problem persists
- if I replace the `OneHotEncode` with an `OrdinalEncoder`, the predictions are equals between sklearn and onnxruntime

@xadupre have you been able to reproduce?

Just to be sure it wasn't related to some float32/float64 strange behaviour, I try to train my model using float32 and I still see huge differences.

For the record, the predictions from sklrean/xgb range from 0 to 1700 and those from onnxruntime range from 0 to 323, with diffs as high as 1400!

I'm not sure what is the best way to reproduce it in a small example, because I'm relying on proprietary data.

issue.title: Support drop option of OneHotEncoder

repository.name: sklearn-onnx
repository.description: Convert scikit-learn models and pipelines to ONNX

issue.body:
Hi,

I tried to use a `OneHotEncoder` with `drop` option set to `first` but when I do so, running the generated model with onnxruntime gives me  the following error during prediction:
```
onnxruntime.capi.onnxruntime_pybind11_state.Fail: [ONNXRuntimeError] : 1 : FAIL : Non-zero status code returned while running OneHotEncoder node. Name:'OneHotEncoder7' Status Message: Unknown Category and zeros = 0.
```

See https://github.com/onnx/sklearn-onnx/issues/321#issuecomment-584052819 for an example of code used to generate and convert the model.

body:
@prabhat00155 @xadupre here is a repro: https://gist.github.com/victornoel/06d6231f6276719ddba53cb381dfd468

I casted an `int` column to `str` because in my original dataset, we have categories made of numbers so I thought this could be related…

As we can see, the differences are huge: the predictions should be between 0 and 1 and the differences can be as big as 1 in my tests!
```
>>> import test
>>> test.test()
[0.9019426  0.91082716 0.91868186 0.94926846 1.0898147 ]
min(Y)-max(Y): 0 1
```

Looks like there is some issue with XGBRegressor converter, not OHE. If you replace XGBRegressor with MLPRegressor, it seems to work fine. Here is the output of test() with MLPRegressor().
```
[2.72400598e-07 2.87338889e-07 2.95446651e-07 3.51248081e-07
 4.55852575e-07]
min(Y)-max(Y): 0 1
```

issue.title: XGBRegressor converter is maybe broken

repository.name: onnxmltools
repository.description: ONNXMLTools enables conversion of models to ONNX

issue.body:
It seems there are problems with the `XGBRegressor` converter.

I've opened an issue at sklearn-onnx but they redirected me to here: https://github.com/onnx/sklearn-onnx/issues/321

Here is a repro: https://gist.github.com/victornoel/06d6231f6276719ddba53cb381dfd468

I casted an int column to str because in my original dataset, we have categories made of numbers so I thought this could be related…

As we can see, the differences are huge: the predictions should be between 0 and 1 and the differences can be as big as 1 in my tests!
```
>>> import test
>>> test.test()
[0.9019426  0.91082716 0.91868186 0.94926846 1.0898147 ]
min(Y)-max(Y): 0 1
```

body: I didn't realise that the converter for XGBRegressor wasn't here earlier, I've opened an issue at onnxmltools: https://github.com/onnx/onnxmltools/issues/371

For the record, I tested latest git version of sklearn-onnx, onnxconverter-common and onnxmltools and the problem is still there…

Any way to get some feedbacks on this maybe?

I suppose this issue can now be closed, according to onnx/onnxmltools#371, the problem is caused by onnxruntime not supporting sparse matrix. Using `sparse=False` in the OneHotEncoder solves the problem.
